Article Title: Foxtail Millet, Gongura Paneer & more: Inside all-vegetarian dinner at PM’S residence for NDA MPs - what was on the menu?
Article Text:
What was on the menu?



NEW DELHI: A specially curated vegetarian spread, from seasonal vegetables to spiced cottage cheese curry was served at a dinner hosted by Prime Minister Narendra Modi for MPs of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) at his residence, 7 Lok Kalyan Marg, in New Delhi on Thursday.The MPs travelled together in buses for the gathering, which featured an elaborate vegetarian menu rooted in regional flavours, seasonal produce and millet-based dishes.The dinner menu mentioned refreshing beverages, including Orange Juice with Ginger and Pomegranate Juice, followed by Subz Badam Shorba, a warm blend of seasonal vegetables, almonds and spices.A variety of appetisers and mains showcased India’s diverse culinary traditions. These included: Kakum Matar Akhrot Ki Shammi (foxtail millet with green peas and crushed walnut), Kothimbir Vadi (flavorful snack made with coriander leaves and gram flour), Gongura Paneer (spiced cottage cheese curry with sorrel leaves), Khubani Malai Kofta (apricot stuffed dumpling in rich creamy cashew curry), Gajar Methi Matar (tempered red carrots and fresh peas with fenugreek leaves), Bhindi Sambhariya (okra with sesame, peanut and jaggery), and Palakura Pappu (Andhra style tempered lentils with spinach).The rice selection featured Kale Moti Chilgoza Pulao, cooked with basmati rice, black gram and toasted pine nuts. This was accompanied by an assortment of Indian breads like, Roti, Missi Roti, Naan, and Tawa Laccha Paratha.The dessert spread featured Baked Pista Langcha, which is a sweet made with chhena and khoya, along with Ada Pradaman, made with rice flakes simmered in palm jaggery and coconut milk with dry fruits. The menu also included fresh cut fruits, and Kahwah, bringing a warm and comforting finish to the wholesome meal.After the gathering, the PM Modi posted on X, expressing delight at hosting the NDA MPs. "The NDA family represents a shared commitment to good governance, national development and regional aspirations," he wrote on X. "Together, we will continue working to strengthen our nation’s development journey in the years ahead," he added.The dinner came shortly after the NDA’s sweeping victory in the Bihar Assembly elections , where the coalition secured 202 of 243 seats. BJP won 89 seats, JD(U) 85, LJP (Ram Vilas) 19, Hindustani Awam Morcha (Secular) five, and Rashtriya Lok Morcha four.Earlier this week, NDA leaders from Bihar felicitated the Prime Minister for the win. PM Modi urged them to work with "more vigour" and reminded them that "with great victory comes great responsibility."BJP MP Anurag Thakur thanked the Prime Minister for the invitation and remarked confidently that the next such dinner would be held after a victory in the 2026 West Bengal elections. "Ab Bihar ke baad agla bhoj Bengal ki jeet ke baad phir hoga," he said.Union minister Kiren Rijiju also posted on X, calling the gathering warm and familial, "NDA MPs from North-East and some of very distinguished MPs riding a bus to Prime Minister's residence… A family atmosphere throughout."This vegetarian spread follows the state banquet hosted at Rashtrapati Bhavan last week for Russian President Vladimir Putin.That menu included dishes such as Murungelai Chaaru, Gucchi Doon Chetin, Kaale Chane Ke Shikampuri, Zafrani Paneer Roll, Achaari Baingan, Dry Fruit and Saffron Pulao, and desserts like Badam Ka Halwa and Kesar-Pista Kulfi, along with fresh fruit, pickles and traditional accompaniments.
Article Summary: PM Narendra Modi hosted a dinner for MPs of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) at his residence, 7 Lok Kalyan Marg, in New Delhi. The MPs travelled together in buses for the gathering, which featured an elaborate vegetarian menu rooted in regional flavours, seasonal produce and millet-based dishes.

Article Title: ‘Have you allowed e-cigarettes?’: BJP MP questions Om Birla; alleges TMC MPs smoked inside Parliament
Article Text:
File photo

BJP Charges TMC MP of Smoking Inside Parliament After Giriraj-Sougata Face-off Over E-Cigarette

NEW DELHI: The Bharatiya Janta Party MP Anurag Thakur on Thursday asked the Lok Sabha speaker Om Birla whether he had allowed e-cigarettes inside the House, accusing the Trinamool Congress MPs of "continuously vaping" in the Parliament.“I just want to request something so that the House knows. E-Cigarettes are banned in the country. Have you (Speaker) allowed it in the House? TMC MPs are using e-cigarettes in the House,” Thakur said.Responding to the question, Birla said that no such permission had been given and vowed to take "strict action" such things "come to light."“It has not been permitted. All members are expected to follow the rules. If such things come to light, I will take strict action,” Lok Sabha Speaker said.The TMC has not made any comments on the matter yet.Several BJP MPs pressed for action against the opposition member, prompting loud protests in the House.Speaker Om Birla appealed for calm and reminded members to uphold parliamentary decorum, adding that he would act if a formal written complaint was submitted, according to news agency PTI.E-cigarettes, he noted, have been prohibited in India for several years.
Article Summary: BJP MP Anurag Thakur accused Trinamool Congress MPs of "continuously vaping" in the Parliament. Lok Sabha speaker Om Birla said that no such permission had been given and vowed to take "strict action" such things "come to light"

Article Title: EC extends timeline for SIR in 5 states & 1 UT, final rolls in February
Article Text:
The Election Commission has adjusted the special intensive revision schedule for poll rolls in several states and a Union Territory. New deadlines for submitting enumeration forms and publishing draft electoral rolls have been set, with final rolls expected in February 2026. This revision aims to ensure all eligible voters are included.

'PM Modi Hacks Hearts, Not EVM': Kangana Ranaut Lambasts Rahul Gandhi During SIR Debate In Lok Sabha

Bengal draft poll rolls will be out on December 16: EC

NEW DELHI: Following requests from chief electoral officers, Election Commission revised Thursday the schedule for the ongoing special intensive revision (SIR) of poll rolls in five states and a UT.The last date to submit enumeration forms in Tamil Nadu and Gujarat has now been fixed as Dec 14, while the draft electoral rolls will be published on Dec 19. The exercise will conclude on Dec 18 in MP, Chhattisgarh and Andaman & Nicobar Islands, while their draft rolls will be published Dec 23. The final date for the submission of enumeration forms and the publication of draft electoral roll in UP has been decided as Dec 26 and Dec 31, respectively.In the earlier revised schedule, the enumeration period for the five states and the UT was until Dec 11 and publication of the draft electoral rolls was Dec 16."In order to ensure that no eligible elector is left behind, new electors are being encouraged to fill up Form 6 along with the declaration and submit them to BLOs, or fill the form and declaration online... to get their names included in the final electoral rolls, which will be published in Feb 2026," EC stated.EC said the enumeration period for Goa, Gujarat, Lakshadweep, Rajasthan and WB ended as per previous revised schedule on Dec 11, and the draft electoral rolls will be published on Dec 16. The schedule for Kerala was revised earlier, and the enumeration period for the state will end by Dec 18, with the draft electoral roll being published on Dec 23.The poll panel had stated Wednesday that CEOs of all states and UTs where SIR was under way will ensure that booth-wise lists of voters marked as absent, shifted, or dead/duplicate are shared with booth-level agents of political parties before the publication of draft rolls. The list will include the names of electors who could not be contacted even after three or more visits by booth-level officers.
Article Summary: The last date to submit enumeration forms in Tamil Nadu and Gujarat has now been fixed as Dec 14. The exercise will conclude on Dec 18 in MP, Chhattisgarh and Andaman & Nicobar Islands. Final rolls expected in February 2026. This revision aims to ensure all eligible voters are included.

Article Title: Anurag Thakur says TMC MP vapes in House, stirs uproar
Article Text:
Lok Sabha proceedings saw a brief disruption when BJP MP Anurag Thakur alleged a Trinamool Congress member was repeatedly using an e-cigarette in the House. Speaker Om Birla, confirming no such permission was granted, assured action if the information is substantiated. The incident prompted calls for decorum and adherence to rules from the treasury benches.

NEW DELHI: Lok Sabha proceedings were disrupted briefly during Question Hour on Thursday after BJP's Anurag Thakur accused an unnamed Trinamool Congress MP of "constantly smoking e-cigarette" in the House for several days. Lok Sabha Speaker Om Birla promised action in the matter."Sir, this is for the information of the House; e-cigarettes have been banned in the country, but have you allowed it in the House?" Thakur asked the Speaker, who told him that no such permission has been granted to anyone.The BJP MP from Hamirpur (Himachal Pradesh) then demanded action against the TMC MP. There was a brief uproar in the House as other MPs from Treasury bench too sought action. It was not immediately clear who the person in question was even as all attention shifted to the TMC bench.Speaker Birla requested all MPs to maintain the decorum of the House and desist from such activities and follow rules. "If I get any such information, I will certainly take action," he assured the members.
Article Summary: BJP's Anurag Thakur accused an unnamed Trinamool Congress MP of "constantly smoking e-cigarette" in the House. Speaker Om Birla assured action if the information is substantiated. The incident prompted calls for decorum and adherence to rules from the treasury benches.
